body: #4225 only seems to affect the settings dialog, not the auto config wizard. I think the wizard needs fixing also.

OBS's auto-config also doesn't appear to have any check for resolutions over 4096.  If the PC's display has a resolution of >4096 pixels on any one side you'll end up in a situation where auto-config will set the output resolution to some high resolution the encoder can't handle.

With the same approach as in #4225, fix the canvas resolution calculation in the auto-config utility. This fixes #4298.

### Motivation and Context
The current release version of OBS has several issues when determining the canvas resolution. This initially occurred due to the Qt update to 5.15.2. While this was fixed for a new profile in a previous commit, I fixed it in the settings screen in #4225. However, now I noticed that thanks to #4298 that I did not adjust this in the auto-config utility. 

This PR adds this.

_Note: In the filed issue, @energizerfellow mentioned that OBS calculates a weird output resolution for screens >4096 pixels in either dimension. Maybe that's worth looking into? I haven't checked this issue and this PR won't change anything to it, but given that this fix will usually cause an increase in the determined canvas resolution, I think it might be worth looking into at some point._

### OBS Studio Log URL

N/A

### OBS Studio Crash Log URL

_No response_

### Expected Behavior

On device with only one 3840*2400 display attached, the Auto-Configuration Wizard "Video Settings" page resolution dropdown contains option "Use Current (3840x2400)".

### Current Behavior

On device with only one 3840*2400 display attached, the Auto-Configuration Wizard "Video Settings" page resolution dropdown contains option "Use Current (1920x1080)".

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch OBS built from current master on Windows 10 device with active screen running at 3840x2400
2. Open Auto-Configuration Wizard, go to "Video Settings" page
3. Open "Base (Canvas) Resolution)" and see options "Use Current (1920x1080)" and "Display 1 (3840x2400)"
4. Of cource, display 1 and current display are the same thing and should have the same resolution.

### Anything else we should know?

#4393 fixed display resolution of devices listed as "Display #", but not the active one. Also, this bug probably affects other users of `obs_get_video_info()`.

Image for your convinience:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45960703/112623819-e0c3a700-8e3d-11eb-8b2c-7183c4bdb8ce.png)
